item.description:
The ‘Squog – The Story of a West Side Neighborhood

Illustrated Lecture

Saturday, September 15, 2012

10:30 a.m.-12:00 p.m.

$10 general public - FREE Manchester Historic Association members

 

The history of the ‘Squog begins in the 18th century with the story of the great pine logs being dragged down Mast Road to the Merrimack River, destined for the shipyards of the King of England. Piscataquog Village, built along the stagecoach road from Concord, New Hampshire to Boston, Massachusetts, was originally the busy commercial center of Bedford. Later it became home to many immigrants, including the Germans who have had such a deep impact on the history of Manchester. This lecture will be presented by Aurore Eaton, Executive Director, who wrote about the ‘Squog neighborhood in her “Looking Back” column for the New Hampshire Union Leader.

 

Photo:  The German School.
item.name: The 'Squog - The Story of a West Side Neighborhood
